eta.util.tt.matchÔÉÅ

Methods for matching a TT pattern to an S-expression and filling in a corresponding template.

Contains a Python reimplementation of the original LISP tree transduction (TT) functions defined here: https://github.com/bkane2/eta/tree/master/core/tt

Functions

flatten_sequences(expr)[source]ÔÉÅ

Flatten lists marked as sequences, i.e., of the form [:seq, ...].

[:seq, ...] expressions are not allowed to contain such expressions as sequence elements (i.e., these would not be flattened. It would be easy to allow them, but for the pattern transductions here no such embeddings occur, because sequence expressions are match-values of single sequence variables, like *atom or +expr, and these are matched only against input expressions free of sequence expressions.)

A top-level expr like [:seq, a] or [:seq, []] or [:seq, [a, b]] becomes a, [], or [a, b] respectively, i.e., a 1-element sequence is turned into that one element. However, an empty sequence [:seq] or longer sequence like [:seq, a, b] is left unchanged, since removing [:seq, ...] doesn‚Äôt leave a single valid expression.

indexed_element_of(expr, index)[source]ÔÉÅ

Obtains the element of an expression located at a nested index (an integer or list of integers).

s_variant_of_p_var(p_var)[source]ÔÉÅ

Return the *-variant of the given +-var.

val(var, expr)[source]ÔÉÅ

Determine whether a predicate is true of a given expression.

If var is a multi-character atom starting with ‚Äò!‚Äô, then it‚Äôs expected to have a function definition corresponding to the string following the ‚Äò!‚Äô. If it starts with ?/*/+ then the corresponding !-predicate must be obtained through string manipulation. If var is a nonnegative integer then the corresponding predicate is !expr, which is true of any expression.

Parameters:

  • var (str) ‚Äì Either a non-negative integer or a match variable with {!,?,*,+} as a prefix.

  • expr (s-expr) ‚Äì An S-expression to check.

Return type:

bool

isa(x, feat, feats)[source]ÔÉÅ

Determine whether a given word has a given feature.

NB: an atom is always assumed to have itself as a feature. If this is not desired, define it as a custom !predicate rather than a feature.

Parameters:

  • x (str) ‚Äì A word (e.g., surgeon or doctor).

  • feat (str) ‚Äì A feature string (e.g., professional).

  • feats (dict) ‚Äì A dict mapping words to feature lists.

Return type:

bool

match(pa, ex, feats={})[source]ÔÉÅ

Match a given pattern S-expression to an input S-expression.

:nil results from match_rec are mapped to an empty list, under the assumption that the match_rec([], []) case is unnecessary for Eta rule trees.

Parameters:

  • pa (s-expr) ‚Äì

    A pattern, which is any S-expression where atoms may be:

    • A custom predicate of form !<pred>, ?<pred>, *<pred>, or +<pred>, interpreted as matching exactly one expression, 0 or 1 expression, 0 or more expressions, or 1 or more expressions, respectively. Custom predicates must be defined in eta.util.tt.preds. Some basic ones are ‚Äòexpr‚Äô, ‚Äòatom‚Äô, and ‚Äòlst‚Äô, being true respectively of any expression, an atom, or a list.

    • An integer >= 0, where 0, 1, 2, ‚Ä¶ respectively mean ‚Äúzero or more expressions‚Äù, ‚Äúat most one expression‚Äù, ‚Äúat most 2 expressions‚Äù, at most 3 expressions‚Äù, etc.

    • A dotted atom, such as .verb or .branch-of-math, i.e., starting with a dot and denoting features of atoms, as defined by the ‚Äòfeats‚Äô argument. These are matched by checking whether a given expression is connected to the feature through a chain of ‚Äòisa‚Äô connections.

    • Any other atom, which simply matches an identical atom in ex.

  • ex (s-expr) ‚Äì The input to match.

  • feats (dict) ‚Äì A dict mapping a word w to a feature list x1, ‚Ä¶, xk, such that isa(w, xi) for each feature xi.

Returns:

An empty list [] if no match, otherwise an S-expression containing the result of the match. The result will resemble the input expression ex, except that sequences of 0 or more constituents matched by sequence variables will be encoded as [:seq, <item1>, <item2>, ...].

Return type:

s-expr

spec_function(x)[source]ÔÉÅ

Check if x is a user-defined evaluable function, i.e., if it ends with ‚Äò!‚Äô.

position_index(i)[source]ÔÉÅ

Map a string denoting a position index to either an integer or list of integers (or return [] if not a position index).

check_position_index_syntax(i)[source]ÔÉÅ

Check if i is a valid position index.

A position index in tree transductions can take the following syntax:

  • 0, 1, 2, 3, ‚Ä¶, (equivalently, 0., 1., 2., 3., ‚Ä¶, but NOT 0.0, 1.0, 2.0, 3.0, ‚Ä¶)

  • or 1.1, 1.2, 1.3, ‚Ä¶, 2.1, 2.2, 2.3, ‚Ä¶, etc., (equivalently 1.1., 1.2., 1.3., ‚Ä¶, 2.1., 2.2., 2.3., ‚Ä¶)

  • or 1.1.1, 1.1.2, ‚Ä¶, 1.2.1, 1.2.2, ‚Ä¶, 2.1.1, 2.1.2, ‚Ä¶ etc. (equivalently 1.1.1., 1.1.2., ‚Ä¶, 1.2.1., 1.2.1., 1.2.2., ‚Ä¶ )

Since trailing 0 digits are not allowed (except for standalone 0), an input like ‚Äò13.20‚Äô should be given as ‚Äò13.20.‚Äô.

fill_template(template, match_result)[source]ÔÉÅ

Fill a template containing positional indices with constituents from a match result.

Parameters:

  • template (s-expr) ‚Äì

    An S-expression containing:

    • Positional indicators such as 3, 3.2, 3.3.2, etc., where pieces of match_result are to be placed. E.g., here, the references are to the 3rd element of match_result, the 2nd element of the 3rd element of match_result, etc. The index 0 is special, as it refers to the (flattened) match result as a whole.

    • Evaluable predicates ending in ‚Äò!‚Äô applied to some arguments, e.g., [lex-ulf!, v, 3.2], in which case the result of the predicate called on the given arguments will filled in place. Custom predicates must be defined in eta.util.tt.preds, and their arguments must match the arguments provided in template.

  • match_result (s-expr) ‚Äì An S-expression containing sequence expressions such as [:seq, [a, b], c, [d, [f, g]]].

Returns:

The template filled in with ‚Äúpieces‚Äù from match_result, as indicated by the position indices it contains. If a position index points to a sequence, i.e., [:seq, ...], the elements of the sequence are inserted into the result without the :seq wrapper.

Return type:

s-expr
